sen.j: 渋川 春海（しぶかわはるみ、しぶかわしゅんかい）、寛永16年閏11月（1639年） - 正徳 (日本)5年10月6日 (旧暦)（1715年11月1日）は、江戸時代前期の天文学者、囲碁棋士 (囲碁)、神道家。
sen.e: Harumi SHIBUKAWA (Shunkai SHIBUKAWA) (November 1639-November 1, 1715) was the astronomer, go-player, and Shintoist.
Harumi SHIBUKAWA (Shunkai SHIBUKAWA) (November 1639-November 1, 1715) was an astronomer, go player and Shintoist.

sen.j: 幼名は六蔵、字は春海、順正（晴海とも）、通称は助左衛門、号は新蘆・都翁、霊社号は土守霊社。
sen.e: The names he went by were Rokuzo (childhood name), Harumi (Shunkai) (azana (name used to call adults)), Junsei (Harumi) (azana), Sukezaemon (alias), and his titles were Shinro Tsutsuchi (go) and Doshureisha (reishago).

sen.j: 江戸幕府碁方の安井家1世安井算哲の子として京都に生まれた。
sen.e: He was born as the son of Santetsu YASUI, the first generation of Yasui family, Edo Shogunate Gokata (official professional go player under Edo Shogunate), in Kyoto.

sen.e: He was born in Kyoto, the son of Santetsu YASUI, the first head of the Yasui family and official professional go player under the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

sen.j: 1652年、父の死によって2世安井算哲となるが、安井家はすでに1世算哲の養子安井算知が継いでいたため保井姓を名乗った。
sen.e: He became the second generation Santetsu YASUI upon the death of his father in 1652, but he used the surname of YASUI (保井) since Yasui family already had the adopted son of first generation Santetsu, Sanchi YASUI, inheriting the role.

He became the second generation Santetsu YASUI upon the death of his father in 1652, but wrote the name YASUI with the characters '保井' because the family's adopted son, Sanchi YASUI (written 安井), had become the head of the family.

sen.j: 数学・暦法を池田昌意に、天文暦学を岡野井玄貞に、垂加神道を山崎闇斎に、土御門神道を土御門泰福に学んだ。
sen.e: He learned mathematics and calendar study from Masaoki IKEDA, astronomy from Gentei OKANOI, Suika Shinto from Ansai YAMAZAKI, and Tsuchimikado Shinto from Yasutomi TSUCHIMIKADO.

sen.j: 当時の日本は貞観_(日本)4年（862年）に唐よりもたらされた宣明暦を用いていたため、かなりの誤差が生じていた。
sen.e: Japan at that time used Senmyo Calendar which arrived from Tang in 862 and suffered substantial amount of error.
Japan at that time used the Senmyo Calendar, which had been imported from Tang China in 862 and had acquired significant errors.

sen.e: In oshirogo (go tournament performed before the shogun) of October 17, 1670 against Dosaku HONINBO, he placed the stone first on the tengen and bragged, 'If I lose in this game, I will never place my stone on tengen again in my lifetime.'
